Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: Some trans voters have expressed confusion and fear of discrimination at the ballot box that could discourage them from participating in public life.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: Trans voters are directly impacted by the new laws and rules, making their experiences relevant to the story.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: The full impact of these laws amid new and evolving voter identification laws is not yet clear, in part because of how recent they are — and that, experts say, could mask their harm.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: Experts are cited to provide analysis on the potential consequences of the new laws.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: It’s still unclear how many trans people will be denied affirming identification — and how many will choose not to vote — as a result of these new regulations.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: The uncertainty around the impact of the regulations is relevant to the broader implications of the story.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Advocates are fighting back. They’ve been mobilizing communities and organizing resources to help transgender Americans, an effort aimed at safeguarding their civic rights.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Advocates are actively working to address the challenges faced by transgender Americans, making their actions significant to the story.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: The ripple effect could extend beyond trans people, these advocates warn.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Advocates are providing warnings about the broader implications of the laws, which is relevant to the story's scope.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: At least nine states in the past two years have explicitly regulated gender in this way, according to a tally by the Movement Advancement Project (MAP), which tracks LGBTQ+ policy.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The Movement Advancement Project provides data on the number of states implementing these regulations, adding credibility to the story.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The survey provides statistical evidence of trans voter participation, which is central to the story's focus on voting rights.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Document Sources.Source Justification: The research highlights the broader issue of voter ID requirements, which is relevant to the story's context.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is a chilling effect,” said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis is a leader of an organization directly involved in helping voters navigate ID requirements, making her insights relevant.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans votes count,” said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Ankit Rastogi provides expert analysis based on research conducted by their organization, adding credibility to the story.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID. And so when a state goes out of its way to enforce its message about its belief about sex and gender on a license, and transgender people then have to publicize that when they show other people, it creates a dangerous environment,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn provides legal expertise on the implications of ID laws for transgender individuals.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people,” said Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Rose Saxe provides analysis on the political framing of anti-trans policies, which is relevant to the story's focus.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding,” Diaz said. “And really to scare trans folks from even participating and getting the license if they needed to update it.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz provides insights into the impact of Florida's regulations on transgender individuals, making their perspective relevant.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There’s nothing these laws will do to stop me from living my best life,” she said. “It just puts my energy and passion towards making this place better for me and other trans people.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs shares her lived experience as a transgender voter, adding a personal perspective to the story.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Kansas, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The ACLU is actively involved in addressing voter ID issues, making their actions relevant to the story.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Equality Florida is directly involved in advocacy and education efforts, making their actions significant to the story.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In eight battleground states, the nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: VoteRiders is actively working to assist voters with ID requirements, making their efforts relevant to the story.
